awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Model Theory of Differential and Difference Equations with Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is concerned with differential equations, which relate a quantity to its rate of change with respect to continuous time; difference equations, which relate a quantity to its rate of change with respect to discrete time; and combinations of these. Systems of such equations describe or model behavior and phenomena throughout the sciences; epidemiology, population dynamics, mechanics etc. The project will use methods from model theory, a branch of mathematical logic, to develop or improve procedures for showing consistency (existence of solutions) of systems of such equations, for identifying auxiliary parameters in systems of such equations, and for eliminating unknowns from such systems. The project will also extend the existing classification of sets of solutions from the case of over-determined (or finite-dimensional) systems to under-determined (or infinite-dimensional systems). 

In this focused research group project, the team of researchers studies differential, difference, and differential-difference equations, from the point of view of model theory in the sense of mathematical logic. Among the aims is to provide decision procedures or improve existing decision procedures regarding consistency and elimination. Applications to a variety of modelling problems for physical systems are expected. The proposed research is threefold. The first is to develop efficient algorithms in cases where the existing methods from theories of differential or difference fields provide algorithms in principle. The second is to extend the existing model-theoretic classification of finite-dimensional solution spaces of systems to infinite-dimensional solution spaces, as well as developing methods to apply the classification in practice. The third is to introduce and study new first order theories of rings with operators, whose decision procedures will apply to new examples arising in applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: FOCUSED RESEARCH GROUPS IN MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
Broadly, the project resulted in new theory and algorithms for simplifying and analyzing models given by differential and difference equations using theory and algorithms from algebra and theory from mathematical logic.
In particular, one of the key applied topics the project contributed to was parameter identifiability for ordinary differential equation (ODE) models.

Parameters are identifiable if their values can be recovered from the input-output data of the model. The PIs introduced multi-experiment identifiability to bring the theory closer to the practical reality, showed how one can efficiently calculate the number of needed experiments, and also proved that multi-experimental identifiability is equivalent to input-output identifiability, notion used by several popular identifiability checking software packages. This notion is not equivalent to identifiability but, interestingly, corresponds to the notion of canonical base in model theory in the sense of mathematical logic.

For models with non-identifiable parameters, we developed an algorithm that reparametrizes the model to achieve identifiability whenever possible. Another, related, applied topic the project contributed to was model reduction for ODE models (finding a model with fewer state variables that is equivalent to the given model), which included both theory, efficient algorithms and publicly available software.

The project also supported a postdoctoral scholar, graduate students and supported the participation mainly US-based researchers at an international conference on differential algebra.


Last Modified: 02/12/2024
Modified by: Alexey Ovchinnikov
